   Perciformes, Callionymidae

TI A new genus of freshwater crab of the tribe Kingsleyini Bott, 1970
   (Crustacea: Decapoda: Brachyura: Pseudothelphusidae) with description of
   a new species from Mato Grosso, Brazil.
AU Pedraza, Manuel (manupedrazam@gmail.com) 
   Tavares, Marcos
   Magalhaes, Celio
SO Zootaxa
VL 4173
IS 1
PS 94-100
PD Oct 3 2016
PY 2016
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB A new genus and species of freshwater crab, Melothelphusa apiaka n.
   gen., n. sp., from Mato Grosso, Central Brazil is described and
   illustrated. Brasiliothelphusa dardanelosensis Magalhaes & Turkay, 2010,
   is assigned to the new genus Melothelphusa. Therefore, the genus
   Brasiliothelphusa Magalhaes & Turkay, 1986, is restricted to its type
   species B. tapajoense Magalhaes & Turkay, 1986. The new taxa can be
   easily separated from their close relatives by a suite of morphological
   characters from the first gonopod.

PT J
AN ZOOR15403013300
DT Article
TI Phylogeography of Koramius charltonius (Gray, 1853) (Lepidoptera:
   Papilionidae): a case of too many poorly circumscribed subspecies.
AU Korb, Stanislav K. (stanislavkorb@list.ru) 
   Fric, Zdenek F.
   Bartonova, Alena
SO Nota Lepidopterologica
VL 39
IS 2
PS 169-191
PD Oct 2 2016
PY 2016
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Koramius charltonius (Gray, 1853) (Lepidoptera: Papilionidae) is
   distributed in the mountains of Central Asia. We analysed genetic and
   phylogeographic patterns throughout the western part of its range using
   a mitochondrial marker (COI). We also analysed the wing pattern using
   multivariate statistics. We found that the species contains several
   unique haplotypes in the west and shared haplotypes in the east. The
   haplotype groups do not correspond to the wing pattern and also the
   described subspecies do not correspond to either the haplotypes or the
   groups circumscribed by the wing pattern. Currently, there are more than
   ten subspecies of K. charltonius in Central Asia; based on our analyses
   we suggest a reduction to only five of them. The following nomenclatural
   changes are applied: (1) K. charltonius aenigma Dubatolov & Milko, 2003,
   syn. n., K. charltonius sochivkoi Churkin, 2009, syn. n., and K.
   charltonius alrashid Churkin & Pletnev, 2012, syn. n. are new synonyms
   of K. charltonius romanovi (Grum-Grshimailo, 1885); (2) K. charltonius
   marusya Churkin & Pletnev, 2012, syn. n., K. charltonius eugenia
   Churkin, 2009, syn. n., K. charltonius anjuta Stshetkin & Kaabak, 1985,
   syn. n., and K. charltonius mistericus Kaabak, Sotchivko & Titov, 1996,
   syn. n. are new synonyms of K. charltonius vaporosus (Avinov, 1913); and
   (3) K. charltonius safronovi Korb, Shaposhnikov, Zatakovoy & Nikolaev,
   2013, syn. n. is a new synonym of K. charltonius voigti (Bang-Haas,
   1927).
C1 Korb, Stanislav K.; Russian Acad Sci, Ural Div, Kommunisticheskaya 28,
   Syktyvkar, 167982, Russia, Russia.
EM stanislavkorb@list.ru

TI Platypeltoides hammondi (Trilobita, Nileidae): A new species from the
   Upper Tremadoc of the Dra Valley, Morocco.
AU Corbacho, Joan (fosilart@hotmail.com) 
   Lopez-Soriano, Francisco J.
SO Batalleria
VL 23
PS 11-19
PD Oct 2016
PY 2016
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Platypeltoides hammondi is here described as a new species. It comes
   from the Lower Fezouata Formation, Lower Ordovician (Tremadoc) of the
   south of Tansikht, Dra Valley, Morocco. It is characterized by the
   presence of genal spines, a characteristic that has not previously
   described in this genus. In addition, we discuss the problematic
   description of Platypeltoides magrebiensis? Rabano, 1990, on the basis
   of new material found in this same locality.

TI Rhyncholampas grignonensis (Defrance, 1825) (Echinoidea, Eoceno) in
   Spain. Review of synonymy.
FT Rhyncholampas grignonensis (Defrance, 1825) (Echinoidea, Eoceno) en
   Espana. Revision de la sinonimia.
AU Francisco Carrasco, Jose (jcarrasc@xtec.cat) 
SO Batalleria
VL 23
PS 35-41
PD Oct 2016
PY 2016
LA Spanish
U1 0
U2 0
AB Rhyncholampas grignonensis is quoted in the middle Eocene of Spain. The
   specimens of this paper represent the first mention in the NE of Spain.
   Some closely related species are compared with this species. It must be
   concluded that all they belong to Rhyncholampas grignonensis. The
   following species: Pygorhynchus desnoyersi Desor, 1858; Pygorhynchus
   gregoirei Cotteau, 1880 and Pygorhynchus botellae Cotteau, 1890 are
   synonyms of Rhyncholampas grignonensis.

DT Article
TI A new species of semiaquatic Anolis (Squamata: Dactyloidae) from Oaxaca
   and Veracruz, Mexico.
AU Gray, Levi
   Meza-Lazaro, Rubi
   Poe, Steven
   Nieto-Montes de Oca, Adrian (anietomontesdeoca@me.com) 
SO Herpetological Journal
VL 26
IS 4
PS 253-262
PD Oct 2016
PY 2016
LA English
U1 1
U2 4
AB We describe a new species of semiaquatic Anolis (A. purpuronectes) from
   the Chimalapas region of eastern Oaxaca and adjacent Veracruz, Mexico,
   and investigate its phylogenetic relationships with the closely related
   species A. barkeri to which the populations under investigation have
   previously been assigned to. Anolis barkeri and the new species appear
   to be allopatric, and differ primarily in male dewlap colour (red and
   orange in A. barkeri, pale purple in A. purpuronectes). A partitioned
   Bayesian analysis of the mitochondrial genes encoding ND1 (part), ND2,
   and the intervening tRNAs revealed that A. barkeri and A. purpuronectes
   are genetically distinct (uncorrected genetic distance between
   them=11.5%), nested within the A. schiedii group as sister species, and
   most closely related to a clade composed of A. cymbops, A. milleri, and
   A. parvicirculatus.
C1 Nieto-Montes de Oca, Adrian; Univ New Mexico, Museum Southwestern Biol,
   Albuquerque, NM, 87131, USA, USA.
EM anietomontesdeoca@me.com
SC Zoology
SN 0268-0130
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Diagnosis; Land zones; Nearctic
   region; North America
DE Anolis purpuronectes [Mexico /  / New species]. 
TN Chordates; Reptiles; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Reptilia, Lepidosauria, Squamata,
   Sauria, Iguanidae
OR Anolis barkeri - Meyer 1968 (Iguanidae): [Diagnostic characters, P.
   255]. 
   Anolis purpuronectes (Iguanidae): [Sp nov, Mexico, P. 256]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR15306034831

AN ZOOR15306034643
PM 28127361
DT Article
TI Microscopic and Molecular Detection of Cryptosporidium andersoni and
   Cryptosporidium xiaoi in Wastewater Samples of Tehran Province, Iran.
AU Hatam-Nahavandi, Kareem
   Mohebali, Mehdi
   Mahvi, Amir-Hossein
   Keshavarz, Hossein
   Najafian, Hamid-Reza
   Mirjalali, Hamed
   Rezaei, Sasan
   Rezaeian, Mostafa (rezaiian@tums.ac.ir) 
SO Iranian Journal of Parasitology
VL 11
IS 4
PS 499-506
PD Oct 2016
PY 2016
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Background: As a waterborne pathogen, Cryptosporidium is one of the most
   common causes of gastroenteritis in human and hoofed livestock animals.
   This study aimed to investigate the distribution of Cryptosporidium spp.
   in human and livestock wastewaters in Iran, by the 18S rRNA sequence
   analysis. Methods: A total of 54 raw wastewater samples collected from
   three urban treatment plants and two slaughterhouses during 2014-2015 in
   Tehran, Iran. The presence of the Cryptosporidium oocysts was assessed
   by immunofluorescence with monoclonal antibodies. To characterize the
   oocysts at the molecular level, the 18S rRNA gene of Cryptosporidium was
   PCR amplified and sequenced. Results: Of the 54 wastewater samples
   examined, 34 (62.9%) were positive for Cryptosporidium oocysts using the
   IFA. Of these, 70.5% (24/34) were positive by PCR, that 91.6% (22/24)
   were successfully sequenced. The species of C. andersoni (95.4%) and C.
   xiaoi (4.6%) were detected in livestock wastewater samples. Conclusion:
   C. andersoni was the major Cryptosporidium sp. found in the aquatic
   environmental wastewater samples. The high rate of detection of C.
   andersoni in domestic wastewater was probably the result of the
   predominancy of this species in cattle herds in Iran. The current study
   is the first report of C. xiaoi in Iran.
C1 Rezaeian, Mostafa; Tehran Univ Med Sci, Sch Publ Hlth, Tehran, Iran,
   Iran.
EM rezaiian@tums.ac.ir
RI Mirjalali, Hamed/J-7247-2019; hatam-Nahavandi, kareem/AAV-8315-2020
OI Mirjalali, Hamed/0000-0002-2568-9022; hatam-Nahavandi,
   kareem/0000-0001-5571-5474
SC Environmental Sciences &Ecology; Zoology
SN 1735-7020
BD Habitat; Man made habitat; Land zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Asia
DE Cryptosporidium andersoni [Sewage habitat / Human & livestock
   wastewaters / Microscopic & molecular detection] [Iran / Tehran Province
   / ]. 
   Cryptosporidium xiaoi [Sewage habitat / Human & livestock wastewaters /
   Microscopic & molecular detection] [Iran /  / New record] [ / Tehran
   Province / ]. 
TN Protozoans
ST Protozoa, Apicomplexa, Sporozoea, Coccidia
OR Cryptosporidium andersoni (Coccidia). 
   Cryptosporidium xiaoi (Coccidia): [New record]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR15306034643
OA DOAJ Gold
DA 2020-09-17
ER

DT Article
TI New Korean records of two amoeboid Protozoa (Protist); Vannella bursella
   and Pseudoparamoeba sp.
AU Lee, Won Je (wonje@kyungnam.ac.kr) 
SO Journal of Species Research
VL 5
IS 3
PS 381-384
PD Oct 2016
PY 2016
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Two marine amoebae Vannella bursella (Page, 1974) Smirnov et al., 2007
   and Pseudoparamoeba sp. were encountered from marine coastal waters of
   Masan Bay and Garorim Bay (Korea), respectively. These species are
   described with uninterpreted records based on light-microscopy of living
   cells and reported taxonomically for the first time from Korea.
   Diagnostics of these species are as follows. Vannella bursella: size in
   vivo, 17-29 [mu]m long with flattened ovoid, semicircular locomotive
   forms. Pseudoparamoeba sp.: size in vivo, 10-15 [mu]m long with
   elongated locomotive forms, producing a few short conical pseudopodia
   from anterior hyaline zone.
C1 Lee, Won Je; Kyungnam Univ, Dept Urban Environm Engn, Changwon, 51767,
   South Korea, South Korea.
EM wonje@kyungnam.ac.kr

   systematics].

   Amoebida

   Vannella bursella - Page 1974 (Amoebida): [New record].

DT Article
TI A new species of the genus Apseudomorpha Miller (Crustacea, Peracarida,
   Tanaidacea) from Korea.
AU Hwang, Hosung
   Kim, Il-Hoi (ihkim@gwnu.ac.kr) 
SO Journal of Species Research
VL 5
IS 3
PS 385-392
PD Oct 2016
PY 2016
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new species of Tanaidacea is described from the eastern coast of
   Korea, under the name of Apseudomorpha magna in the family
   Metapseudidae. The new species can be distinguished from its congeners
   by the following combination of characters: pleonites 2 and 5 and
   pleotelson have a large lateral seta; pleopods are biramous, in five
   pairs, each bearing a two-segmented exopod and a single-segmented
   endopod; the maxillular palp is two-segmented, with five setae on its
   distal segment; the pleotelson has a large seta on each anterolateral
   process; and the mandibular palp has 2, 7, and 13 setae on the first to
   third segments, respectively.
C1 Kim, Il-Hoi; Gangneung Wonju Natl Univ, Dept Biol, Gangneung, 25457,
   South Korea, South Korea.
EM ihkim@gwnu.ac.kr
SC Zoology
SN 2234-7909

   385].

AN ZOOR15306038622
DT Article
TI Siphonostomatoid copepods (Crustacea) mainly associated with marine
   invertebrates from Korean waters.
AU Kim, Il-Hoi (ihkim@gwnu.ac.kr) 
SO Journal of Species Research
VL 5
IS 3
PS 393-442
PD Oct 2016
PY 2016
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Twelve species of siphonostomatoid copepods mainly associated with
   marine invertebrates are recorded from Korean waters. Nine species are
   new to science: Arctopontius minutus n. sp., A. adelphus n. sp, and
   Dyspontius alatus n. sp. in the family Artotrogidae; Asterocheres
   horridus n. sp., A. cuspis n. sp., A. quadridens n. sp., Scottocheres
   mipoensis n. sp., Asteropontoides acutirostris n. sp. and Callomyzon
   macrocephalus n. gen. n. sp. in the family Asterocheridae. The new genus
   Callomyzon is distinguished from other genera in the family by having
   six setae on the third endopodal segment of leg 3, four spines and three
   setae on the third exopodal segment of leg 4 and three setae on the
   third endopodal segment of leg 4. Three new records of Korea,
   Asterocheres lilljeborgi Boeck, 1859 and A. simulans (T. Scott, 1898) in
   the Asterocheridae, and Parartotrogus arcticus T. and A. Scott, 1901 in
   the Cancerillidae are redescribed as the circum-Arctic species.
C1 Kim, Il-Hoi; Korea Inst Coastal Ecol Inc, 802 Ho,302 Dong,397 Seokcheon
   Ro, Bucheon, Gyeonggi Do, 14449, South Korea, South Korea.
EM ihkim@gwnu.ac.kr

DT Article
TI Ten new species of genus Sarcotragus (Demospongiae: Dictyoceratida:
   Irciniidae) from Korea.
AU Sim, Chung Ja (cjsim@hnu.kr) 
   Lee, Kyung Jin
   Kim, Hyung June
SO Journal of Species Research
VL 5
IS 3
PS 443-458
PD Oct 2016
PY 2016
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Ten new species of genus Sarcotragus (Demospongiae: Dictyoceratida:
   Irciniidae) are described from Geomundo Island and Jejudo Island, Korea.
   All new species of the Sarcotragus are distinguished from the other
   reported species of Sarcotragus by the skeletal structure, especially
   fasciculate primary fibres. The characters of genus Sarcotragus have
   cylindrical primary fascicles filled with wads of filaments or flattened
   fascicles. All of the primary fibres are not cored with foreign debris.
   Secondary fibres have slightly fasciculate branch or plastic-like web.
   They are all not cored with foreign debris. All skeletal fibres are very
   irregular. The surface is covered with loose or tight filamentous
   membrane.
C1 Sim, Chung Ja; Hannam Univ, Dept Biol Sci & Biotechnol, Daejeon, 34430,
   South Korea, South Korea.
EM cjsim@hnu.kr

PT J
AN ZOOR15306038624
DT Article
TI First report of the branchiobdellidan Holtodrilus truncatus (Annelida:
   Clitellata) found on the freshwater atyid shrimp Neocaridina sp from
   Korea.
AU Ahn, Dong-Ha
   Min, Gi-Sik (mingisik@inha.ac.kr) 
SO Journal of Species Research
VL 5
IS 3
PS 459-462
PD Oct 2016
PY 2016
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The branchiobdellidan species Holtodrilus truncatus (Liang, 1963) is
   reported for the first time in Korea. The genus Holtodrilus Gelder and
   Brinkhurst, 1990 is monotypic within the family Xironodrilidae, and the
   genus and family of this species are also new to the Korean fauna. The
   branchiobdellidan specimens were collected from the exoskeletons of the
   freshwater atyid shrimp, Neocaridina sp., sampled from the 'Andeok
   Valley', Jeju-do Province, South Korea. Holtodrilus truncatus is
   characterized by its terete body form, 7/7 dental formula (with a large
   medial tooth and three pairs of smaller lateral teeth), and no trunk
   appendages. In addition, we determined a partial sequence of the
   mitochondrial cytochrome c oxidase subunit 1 (CO1) gene as a DNA barcode
   marker for H. truncatus. The present study is the first record of the
   branchiobdellidan occurrence on a non-crayfish host (shrimp) in Korea.
   To date, seven species (four genera in three families) of
   branchiobdellidans have been reported in the Korean fauna.
C1 Min, Gi-Sik; Inha Univ, Dept Biol Sci, Incheon, 22212, South Korea,
   South Korea.
EM mingisik@inha.ac.kr
SC Zoology; Environmental Sciences &Ecology
SN 2234-7909
BD Systematics; Associations; Land zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Asia
DE Holtodrilus; Xironodrilidae [Asia / Korea / New record; systematics]. 
   Holtodrilus truncatus [Associations / Neocaridina (Crustacea) / New
   record; systematics] [Asia / Korea / ] [South Korea / Jeju / Crustacean
   associates]. 
   Neocaridina [Associations / Holtodrilus truncatus (Annelida) / New
   record] [South Korea / Jeju / Annelid associates]. 
TN Annelids; Arthropods; Crustaceans; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Annelida, Arthropoda, Crustacea, Malacostraca, Eumalacostraca,
   Eucarida, Decapoda, Natantia
OR Holtodrilus - Gelder & Brinkhurst 1990 (Annelida): [New record]. 
   Holtodrilus truncatus - (Liang 1963) (Annelida): [New record]. 
   Xironodrilidae - Holt 1986 (Annelida): [New record]. 
   Neocaridina (Natantia): [New record].

DT Article
TI Nine new species of genus Ircinia (Demospongiae: Dictyoceratida:
   Irciniidae) from Korea.
AU Sim, Chung Ja (cjsim@hnu.kr) 
   Lee, Kyung Jin
   Kim, Hyung June
SO Journal of Species Research
VL 5
IS 3
PS 483-497
PD Oct 2016
PY 2016
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Nine new species of genus Ircinia (Demospongiae: Dictyoceratida:
   Irciniidae) from Jejudo Island, Korea are described. All of the new
   species are distinguished from the others reported species of Ircinia by
   the skeletal structure, especially massive fasciculate primary fibres.
   The characters of genus Ircinia have primary fibres cored with foreign
   debris and no cored secondary fibres. Primary fibres are not easy to
   distinguish from secondary fibres if they are not cored. Secondary web
   has perforated plate or meshed net. All new species have loosely
   arranged skeletal fibres network.
C1 Sim, Chung Ja; Hannam Univ, Dept Biol Sci & Biotechnol, Daejeon, 34430,
   South Korea, South Korea.

DT Article
TI Taxonomic study on bryozoans - new additions to the Korean fauna and new
   species of Petraliella from Seogwipo waters of Jeju Island.
AU Chae, Hyun Sook
   Kil, Hyun Jong
   Seo, Ji Eun (jeseo@woosuk.ac.kr) 
SO Journal of Species Research
VL 5
IS 3
PS 551-565
PD Oct 2016
PY 2016
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB This study aims to clarify the diversity of bryozoans which were
   collected from Seogwipo waters in Jeju Island, Korea. A total of 78
   species has been reported from Seogwipo waters so far. In the present
   study, 63 species were found from nine sites of Seogwipo waters from
   2008 to 2012, including six newly added species to the Korean bryozoan
   fauna and twelve species new to Seogwipo waters. As a result of this
   study, the bryozoans from Seogwipo waters were turned out to be 96
   species, 64 genera, 42 families, three orders and two classes.
C1 Seo, Ji Eun; Woosuk Univ, Dept Ecobiol Sci, Jincheon, 27841, South
   Korea, South Korea.
EM jeseo@woosuk.ac.kr

SN 2234-7909

   tenuis; Mucropetraliella philippinesis [North Pacific / Korea / New
   record; systematics]. 
   Petraliella globulata [North Pacific / South Korea / New species].

DT Article
TI Lower Cretaceous shallow-water carbonates and a new lituolid foraminifer
   (Bulbobaculites felixi n. sp.) from the Northern Apuseni Mountains
   (Romania).
AU Ples, George (george.ples@ubbcluj.ro) 
   Bucur, Ioan I.
   Sasaran, Emanoil
SO Facies
VL 62
IS 4
PS 27
PD Oct 2016
PY 2016
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Shallow-water carbonates from the Lower Cretaceous (upper Aptian) of the
   Subpiatra. Quarry (Apuseni Mountains, west Romania) contain a new
   species of lituolid foraminifera of the genus Bulbobaculites. The new
   foraminifer is characterized by a streptospiral initial part, followed
   by a rectilinear adult stage and a test-wall composed of agglutinated
   micritic grains. Within the Subpiatra. limestones, three main facies can
   be distinguished: (a) coastal and littoral, (b) open-shelf/lagoon, and
   (c) shelf margin with bioconstructions and bioclastic shoals. The lower
   part of the succession contains facies typical for peritidal
   environments, with both low-and high-energy subtidal limestones,
   overlain by thinly bedded supratidal limestones. The middle part of the
   section contains dominantly subtidal limestones assigned to the
   open-shelf system, whereas the upper part consists of micro-reefs with
   corals and rudists interlayered with bioclastic shoals. In terms of
   microfacies, the new species of Bulbobaculites is most common in
   bioclastic grainstone/rudstone and floatstone/packstone assigned to the
   coastal/littoral and lagoonal facies.
C1 Ples, George; Univ Babes Bolyai, Dept Geol, M Kogalniceanu 1, Cluj
   Napoca, 400084, Romania, Romania.
EM george.ples@ubbcluj.ro
RI Pleș, George/AAR-5606-2020; Bucur, Ioan I./B-7064-2011
OI Pleș, George/0000-0002-3750-4929; 
SC Zoology
SN 0172-9179
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Palaearctic region;
   Eurasia; Europe; Geological time periods; Mesozoic
DE Bulbobaculites felixi [Romania /  / new species] [Cretaceous /  / ]. 
TN Protozoans
ST Protozoa, Sarcomastigophora, Sarcodina, Rhizopoda, Granuloreticulosea,
   Foraminiferida
OR Bulbobaculites felixi (Foraminiferida): [Sp nov, Romania, Cretaceous, P.
   8; Fossil]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR15305028151
DA 2020-09-17

PT J
AN ZOOR15305027889
DT Article
TI New synonymy to Simulium (Inaequalium) diversibranchium Lutz, with
   comments on the Inaequale species-group (Diptera, Simuliidae).
AU Gil-Azevedo, Leonardo H. (lhgazevedo@mn.ufrj.br) 
   Molina, Oscar Sanchez
SO Revista Brasileira de Entomologia
VL 60
IS 4
PS 293-296
PD Oct 2016
PY 2016
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Simulium (Inaequalium) Coscaron and Wygodzinsky, 1984 is a homogeneous
   subgenus widely spread on the Neotropical Region, which the adults can
   only be reliably identified from linked-reared specimens. Despite many
   revisionary works only a single character of the pupal gill separates
   Simulium diversibranchium Lutz, 1910 from S. mariavulcanoae Coscaron and
   Wygodzinsky, 1984. Specimens of both species show that S. mariavulcanoae
   is a junior synonym of S. diversibranchium. The relationship between S.
   diversibranchium and S. subnigrum Lutz, 1910 needs further
   investigation. Some features of the pupal gill often used as diagnosis
   in Simulium (Inaequalium) species, such as the direction of gill
   filaments or the height of the bifurcation of the secondary or tertiary
   branches of the pupal gill are highly polymorphic, making its use as
   diagnostic character not reliable. (C) 2016 Sociedade Brasileira de
   Entomologia. Published by Elsevier Editora Ltda.
C1 Gil-Azevedo, Leonardo H.; Univ Fed Rio de Janeiro, Museu Nacl, Rio De
   Janeiro, RJ, Brazil, Brazil.
EM lhgazevedo@mn.ufrj.br
RI Molina, Oscar Sanchez/AAA-2746-2020; Gil-Azevedo, Leonardo
   H./H-5246-2011; Nessimian, Jorge L/I-9435-2012
OI Gil-Azevedo, Leonardo H./0000-0002-0389-2185; Sanchez Molina,
   Oscar/0000-0001-9942-0045
SC Respiratory System; Zoology
SN 0085-5626
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; Diagnosis; Synonymy; Taxonomy; Respiration;
   Respiratory system
DE Simulium (Inaequalium) [Gills / Pupal gill characteristics / Taxonomic
   value]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates; True Flies
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Diptera, Nematocera, Simuliidae
OR Simulium (Inaequalium) - Coscaron & Wygodzinsky 1984 (Simuliidae). 
   Simulium (Inaequalium) diversibranchium - Lutz 1910 (Simuliidae):
   [Emended diagnosis, P. 295; Syn nov, Simulium (Inaequalium)
   mariavulcanoae Coscaron & Wygodzinsky 1984, p. 294]. 
   Simulium (Inaequalium) subnigrum - Lutz 1910 (Simuliidae): [Status, P.
   295]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR15305027889
OA DOAJ Gold, Green Published
DA 2020-09-17

DT Article
TI Bees as hosts of mutillid wasps in the Neotropical region (Hymenoptera,
   Apidae, Mutillidae).
AU Luz, David R. (drdaluz@gmail.com) 
   Waldren, George C.
   Melo, Gabriel A.R.
SO Revista Brasileira de Entomologia
VL 60
IS 4
PS 302-307
PD Oct 2016
PY 2016
LA English
U1 1
U2 4
AB A review of bee species used as hosts of mutillid wasps in the
   Neotropical region is presented. Three new confirmed host records are
   provided for the mutillid species Hoplomutilla biplagiata Mickel, 1939,
   Pappognatha limes Mickel, 1939, and Tallium aracati Casal, 1962. Two
   potential host records are provided for Euspinolia rufula Mickel, 1938
   and Lophomutilla inca Fritz and Pagliano, 1993. Additionally, Mutilla
   hoplitiformis Strand, 1909, is transferred to the genus Darditilla.
   Correlations between host nesting habits and female mutillid morphology
   are discussed. Lastly, all known confirmed and potential host records in
   the Neotropical region are compiled. (C) 2016 Sociedade Brasileira de
   Entomologia. Published by Elsevier Editora Ltda.
C1 Luz, David R.; Univ Fed Parana, Dept Zool, Curitiba, Parana, Brazil,

DT Article
TI FURTHER DATA ON THE EXTINCT ANT GENUS EOCENOMYRMA (HYMENOPTERA,
   FORMICIDAE).
AU Radchenko, A.G. (rad@izan.kiev.ua) 
   Dlussky, G.M.
SO Vestnik Zoologii
VL 50
IS 5
PS 395-406
PD Oct 2016
PY 2016
LA English
U1 1
U2 1
AB Eocenomyrma ukrainica sp. n. and E. breviscapa sp. n., two new ant
   species of the extinct genus Eocenomyrma Dlussky et Radchenko, are
   described from the Rovno amber (Late Eocene, Priabonian, 34-38 Ma). E.
   ukrainica (described based on the male and gyne) differs from the
   previously known species of this genus by the shorter propodeal spines
   and by the sculpture of the head and mesosoma. E. breviscapa is
   described based on the single worker and differs from all known
   Eocenomyrma species by the punctated head, mesosoma and waist, by
   another shape of the petiole, by the shorter propodeal spines, and by
   the distinctly shorter antennal scape. Additional data on the record of
   E. rugosostriata (Mayr) and E. orthospina Dlussky et Radchenko is
   provided. A key for the identification of six known Eocenomyrma species
   is compiled. The character of the forewing venation of the male and gyne
   of E. ukrainica supports our idea about relation of this genus and the
   genus Temnothorax Mayr, and placing Eocenomyrma to the tribe
   Formicoxenini.
C1 Radchenko, A.G.; NAS Ukraine, Schmalhausen Inst Zool, Vul B
   Khmelnitskogo 15, Kiev, UA-01030, Ukraine, Ukraine.
EM rad@izan.kiev.ua

SN 0084-5604

   zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Europe; Geological time periods;
   Caenozoic; Tertiary; Palaeogene

TI First Occurrence and Paleo-Ecological Implications of Insects
   (Orthoptera: Ensifera Gryllidae) in the Romualdo Member of the Santana
   Formation, Eo-Cretaceous of the Araripe Basin.
AU Freitas, Luis C.B. (lcgeologia@hotmail.com) 
   De Moura, Geraldo J.B.
   Saraiva, Antonio A.F.
SO Anais da Academia Brasileira de Ciencias
VL 88
IS 4
PS 2113-2120
PD Oct 2016
PY 2016
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB The Romualdo Member of the Santana Formation, a lithostatigraphic unit
   attributed to a marine intrusion, is famous for its preserved fossils in
   calcareous concretions, which stand out for their diversity and
   excellent preservation levels. This paper aims to record the first
   occurrence of the Class Insecta in the Romualdo Member of the Santana
   Formation of the Araripe Basin, as well as to describe and discuss the
   paleoecological implications of such finding. The first occurrence of
   the order Orthoptera (family Gryllidae) is presented for this unit. This
   new species is attributed to the genus Araripegryllus, that lasted
   throughout the deposition of the Crato Member, which is under the
   Romualdo Member. In reference to its statigraphic origin, the specimens
   was named Araripegryllus romualdoi sp. nov.
C1 Freitas, Luis C.B.; Residencia Fortaleza REFO, Serv Geol Brasil, Ave
   Antonio Sales 1418, Fortaleza, CE, BR-60135101 BC, Brazil, Brazil.

DT Article
TI A First Case of Human Trichuriasis from a Roman Lead Coffin in France.
AU Dufour, Benjamin (benjamin.dufour@univ-fcomte.fr) 
   Segard, Maxence
   Le Bailly, Matthieu
SO Korean Journal of Parasitology
VL 54
IS 5
PS 625-629
PD Oct 2016
PY 2016
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB A paleoparasitological study was carried out on 2 lead coffins recovered
   from the Roman site of Jaunay-Clan (near Poitiers, France). For the
   first time, this particular type of burial gave positive parasitological
   results, and eggs of the whipworm Trichuris trichiura were identified in
   1 individual. In the present case, thanatomorphose associated with
   funerary practices may explain the scarcity of the recovered eggs.
   However, human whipworm has now been observed in 9 individuals dated to
   the Roman period. The very high frequency of Trichuris sp. eggs in Roman
   archaeological sites (up to 80%) suggests that fecal peril, hygiene, and
   waste management were problematic during this period. Finally, due to
   the fact that very few analyses have been conducted on human bodies
   dated to the Roman period, more analyses must be performed in the future
   to provide further information about diseases in the Roman world.
C1 Dufour, Benjamin; Univ Bourgogne Franche Comte, CNRS UMR Chronoenvironm
   6249, 16 Route Gray, Besancon, F-25030, France, France.
EM benjamin.dufour@univ-fcomte.fr
RI Le Bailly, Matthieu/AAA-2977-2019

   Benjamin/0000-0002-8075-6881

DT Article
TI Cretaceous (Albian to Turonian) radiolarians from chert blocks of the
   Moni Melange (Southern Cyprus).
AU Bragina, Liubov (l.g.bragina@mail.ru) 
   Bragin, Nikita
SO Revue de Micropaleontologie
VL 59
IS 4
PS 311-338
PD Oct 2016
PY 2016
LA English
U1 1
U2 1
AB Well-preserved Cretaceous (Albian-Turonian) radiolarians were extracted
   from radiolarian-bearing chert olistoliths of the Monagroulli Member
   within the Moni Melange (Campanian-Maastrichtian, Southern Cyprus). Four
   assemblages were distinguished: Middle Albian-Lower Cenomanian (Thanarla
   spoletoensis Zone), Upper Albian-Lower Cenomanian (Thanarla spoletoensis
   Zone, Dorypyle? anisa Subzone), lowermost Turanian (base of Alievium
   superbum Zone) and Lower Turanian (Alievium superbum Zone). The
   radiolarian assemblages are diverse and have taxonomic composition
   similar to coeval assemblages of Italy and Spain. The sediments of the
   Monagroulli Member differ from coeval rocks of the Mamonia Complex
   (western Cyprus) by the more common presence of radiolarian cherts and
   may have been formed in the distal part of a continental margin with
   less input of clastic material. A new spicular radiolarian genus
   Cyprothamnus with 2 new species (C. multifurcatus and C. moniensis) is
   described from the Lower Turonian strata. (C) 2016 Published by Elsevier
   Masson SAS.
C1 Bragina, Liubov; RAS, Inst Geol, Pyzhevsky 7, Moscow, 119017, Russia,
   Russia.
EM l.g.bragina@mail.ru

TI Silurian radiolarians from the Jenolan Caves region, New South Wales,
   Australia.
AU Kachovich, Sarah (s.kachovich@uq.edu.au) 
   Sheng, Jiani
   Aitchison, Jonathan C.
SO Revue de Micropaleontologie
VL 59
IS 4
PS 339-346
PD Oct 2016
PY 2016
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Moderately-preserved Silurian radiolarians have been recovered from the
   Jenolan Caves region, eastern NSW, Australia. Radiolarians were first
   reported from this area in the late 19th Century by T.W. Edgeworth
   David, but were not described in detail, neither were they illustrated.
   Nearly 120 years later, the first images of these fossils are presented.
   The radiolarians reported include: ?Futobari cf. solidus Furutani,
   ?Zadrappolus sp., Haplentactiniid gen. and sp. indet, Borisella sp.,
   ?Palaeoephippium sp., ?Insolitignum vivanima MacDonald and ?Helenifore
   speciosus (Furutani). The fauna is similar to others described from
   Upper Silurian strata in Japan. Crown Copyright (C) 2016 Published by
   Elsevier Masson SAS. All rights reserved.

TI A new species of maimetshid wasp (Insecta: Hymenoptera) in Siberian
   Cretaceous amber.

   Perkovsky, Evgeny E.

VL 102

PS 213-217
PD Oct 2016
PY 2016
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB A new fossil wasp belonging to the extinct evaniomorphan family
   Maimetshidae is described from Santonian amber of Yantardakh, in the
   Taimyr Peninsula, northern Siberia. Iberomaimetsha pallida sp. nov. is
   represented by a single female and is distinguished from the other two
   species of the genus most notably in its wing venation. A modified key
   to the world Maimetshidae is proposed to include the new species. (C)

DT Article
TI The new taxonomic status of Rhea anchorenensis (Ameghino and Rusconi,
   1932) (Aves, Palaeognathae) from the Pleistocene of Argentina.
AU Picasso, Mariana B.J. (mpicasso@fcnym.unlp.edu.ar) 
   Mosto, Clelia
SO Annales de Paleontologie
VL 102
IS 4
PS 237-241
PD Oct 2016
PY 2016
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Rhea anchorenensis (Ameghino and Rusconi, 1932) is an extinct species of
   Rheidae (Aves, Palaeognathae) from the Pleistocene of Buenos Aires
   province, Argentina, only known for a distal fragment of a left
   tarsometatarsus. Since its description in 1932, this specimen was not
   analyzed in an adequately comparative framework with the extant species.
   This study provides a re-description of this specimen and a comparison
   with the extant species of Rheidae with the aim of reevaluating its
   taxonomic identity. The morphological characteristics of the fossil
   specimen are very similar to those of the extant species Rhea americana.
   Consequently, their status as a different species of the genus Rhea is
   no longer valid and Rhea anchorenensis must be considered as junior
   synonym of R. americana. (C) 2016 Elsevier Masson SAS. All rights
   reserved.
C1 Picasso, Mariana B.J.; Univ Nacl La Plata, Div Paleontol Vertebrados,
   Paseo Bosque S-N, La Plata, Buenos Aires, RA-1900, Argentina, Argentina.
EM mpicasso@fcnym.unlp.edu.ar
SC Zoology; Paleontology
SN 0753-3969; 1778-3666

   Neotropical region; South America; Geological time periods; Caenozoic;
   Quaternary

   /  / ].

DT Article
TI Box Jellyfish Alatina alata Has a Circumtropical Distribution.
AU Lawley, Jonathan W. (jonathan.lawley@yahoo.com.br) 
   Ames, Cheryl Lewis
   Bentlage, Bastian
   Yanagihara, Angel
   Goodwill, Roger
   Kayal, Ehsan
   Hurwitz, Kikiana
   Collins, Allen G.
SO Biological Bulletin (Woods Hole)
VL 231
IS 2
PS 152-169
PD Oct 2016
PY 2016
LA English
U1 1
U2 15
AB Species of the box jellyfish (Cubozoa) genus Alatina are notorious for
   their sting along the beaches of several localities of the Atlantic and
   Pacific. These species include Alatina alata on the Caribbean Island of
   Bonaire (the Netherlands), A. moseri in Hawaii, and A. mordens in
   Australia. Most cubozoans inhabit coastal waters, but Alatina is unusual
   in that specimens have also been collected in the open ocean at great
   depths. Alatina is notable in that populations form monthly aggregations
   for spermcast mating in conjunction with the lunar cycle. Nominal
   species are difficult to differentiate morphologically, and it has been
   unclear whether they are distinct or a single species with worldwide
   distribution. Here we report the results of a population genetic study,
   using nuclear and mitochondrial sequence data from four geographical
   localities. Our analyses revealed a general lack of geographic structure
   among Alatina populations, and slight though significant isolation by
   distance. These data corroborate morphological and behavioral
   similarities observed in the geographically disparate localities, and
   indicate the presence of a single, pantropically distributed species,
   Alatina alata. While repeated, human-mediated introductions of A. alata
   could explain the patterns we have observed, it seems more likely that
   genetic metapopulation cohesion is maintained via dispersal through the
   swimming medusa stage, and perhaps via dispersal of encysted planulae,
   which are described here for the first time in Alatina.
C1 Lawley, Jonathan W.; Univ Fed Santa Catarina, Dept Ecol & Zool,
   Florianopolis, SC, BR-88040970 BC, Brazil, Brazil.
EM jonathan.lawley@yahoo.com.br
RI Collins, Allen G/A-7944-2008; Ames, Cheryl/T-2647-2019; W. Lawley,
   Jonathan/S-5825-2016
OI Collins, Allen G/0000-0002-3664-9691; Ames, Cheryl/0000-0003-1132-6834;
   W. Lawley, Jonathan/0000-0003-1267-5294
SC Zoology; Anatomy &Morphology; Biochemistry &Molecular Biology;
   Developmental Biology; Genetics &Heredity; Evolutionary Biology;
   Environmental Sciences &Ecology
SN 0006-3185

   Life cycle and development; Development; Genetics; Evolution; Ecology;

DT Article
TI The genus Incagonum LIEBHERR, 1994 in Peru, with description of four new
   species (Coleoptera, Carabidae, Platynini).
AU Allegro, Gianni (gianni.allegro@crea.gov.it) 
   Giachino, Pier Mauro
   Moret, Pierre
SO Entomologische Blaetter fuer Biologie und Systematik der Kaefer
VL 112
IS 1
PS 11-24
PD Oct 2016
PY 2016
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB Seven species belonging to the genus Incagonum are recorded to date from
   Peru. In addition to the three already known (I. aeneum (REICHE, 1843),
   /. Inca (MORET, 1994) and I. mateui (MORET, 1994)), four new species are
   described: I. opacum n. sp., I. lucidum n. sp., I. hiekei n. sp. from
   Cordillera Blanca, Department Ancash, and I. peruvianum n. sp. from the
   Departments Ancash and Cajamarca. The known distribution is reported for
   all species. A type specimen of most species has also been illustrated,
   as well as male genitalia. Finally, a revised key to all the Incagonum
   species from Peru and Ecuador is provided.
C1 Allegro, Gianni; CREA Consiglio Ric Agr & Anal Econ Agr, Unita Ric Prod
   Legnose Fuori Foresta, Str Frassineto 35, Casale Monferrato, I-15033,
   Italy, Italy.
EM gianni.allegro@crea.gov.it

SN 0013-8835

   Neotropical region; South America

   peruvianum [Peru /  / New species].

PT J
AN ZOOR15303017904
DT Article
TI New species and new records of odacanthine carabid beetles from the
   Oriental, Papuan, and Australian Regions (Coleoptera, Carabidae,
   Odacanthini).
AU Baehr, Martin (martin.baehr@zsm.mwn.de) 
SO Entomologische Blaetter fuer Biologie und Systematik der Kaefer
VL 112
IS 1
PS 25-51
PD Oct 2016
PY 2016
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB As a further supplement to recent papers on Australian and Papuan
   odacanthine carabid beetles, new species of the genera Dicraspeda
   CHUDOIR, 1862, Eudalia CASTELNAU, 1867, and Giachinoana BAEHR, 2003 are
   described; Dicraspeda skalei n. sp. from Western Papua Indonesia,
   related to D. dubia (GESTRO, 1879), Dicraspeda keiana n. sp. from Kei
   Islands, related to D. missai BAEHR, 2006, Eudalia monteithi n. sp. from
   south-eastern Queensland, Australia, related to E. femorata BAEHR, 2005,
   and Giachinoana insulicola n. sp. from islands of the Sir Edward Pellew
   Group off the north-east coast of the Northern Territory of Australia.
   Also six new species of the Oriental genus Mimocolliuris LIEBKE, 1933
   are described: Mimocolliuris hiekei n. sp. and M. hicoloripes n. sp.
   from Nepal, M. hartmanni n. sp. from South Vietnam, M. astoni n. sp.
   from Hong Kong, South China, M. indica n. sp. from central and southern
   India, and M. unimaculata n. sp. from Laos, Sumatra, and Sulawesi. The
   new species of Dicraspeda and Eudalia are introduced into the most
   recent keys to the respective genera. For the species of the genera
   Mimocolliuris and Giachinoana complete new keys are provided. New
   records of some additional Australian and Papuan odacanthine species are
   enumerated. The tribe Odacanthini is first recorded from Tasmania.
C1 Baehr, Martin; Zool Staatssammlung, Munchhausenstr 21, Munich, D-81247,
   Germany, Germany.
EM martin.baehr@zsm.mwn.de

SN 0013-8835

   China; India; Australasia; Australia

DT Article
TI Revision of the Oriental species of the genus Ancus PUTZEYS, 1866
   (Coleoptera, Carabidae, Clivinini).
AU Balkenohl, Michael (mike.balkenohl@bluewin.ch) 
SO Entomologische Blaetter fuer Biologie und Systematik der Kaefer
VL 112
IS 1
PS 53-62
PD Oct 2016
PY 2016
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Oriental members of the genus Ancus PUTZEYS, 1866 are revised. A.
   excavaticeps PUTZEYS, 1866 and A. cariniceps ANDREWES, 1936 arc
   redescribed and a lectotype is designated for the former. The species A.
   hiekei n. sp. from Laos and A. principes n. sp. from Thailand arc
   described. Morphological differences from American and African species
   are discussed, and the A. excavaticeps species group is proposed for the
   Oriental species. A key to the Oriental species is given.
C1 Balkenohl, Michael; Ligusterweg 9, Bonstetten, CH-8906, Switzerland,
   Switzerland.

DT Article
TI Bembidiina of the Afrotropical region: Bembidion subgenus Omotaphus
   NETOLITZKY, 1914 (Coleoptera, Carabidae, Bembidiini).
AU Bonavita, Paolo
   Toledano, Luca (paolo.bonavita@istruzione.it) 
   Maddison, David R.
   Taglianti, Augusto Vigna
SO Entomologische Blaetter fuer Biologie und Systematik der Kaefer
VL 112
IS 1
PS 67-106
PD Oct 2016
PY 2016
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB The twelve known species of the African subgenus Omotaphus NETOLITZKY,
   1914, of the genus Bembidion LATREILLE, 1802 are here revised. We
   propose the following new synonymies (with junior synonym listed first):
   Bembidion stricticolle JEANNEL, 1955 = Bembidion madagascariense
   CHAUDOIR, 1876 n. syn.; Bembidion sperans NETOLITZKY, 1931 = Bembidion
   mellissii WOLLASTON, 1869 n. syn.; Bembidium variegatum BOHEMAN, 1848 =
   Bembidion mellissii WOLLASTON, 1869 n. syn.; Bembidium tumidum GEMMINGER
   & HAROLD, 1868 = Bembidion mellissii WOLLASTON, 1869 n. syn.; Bembidion
   simienense BASILEWSKY, 1957 = Bembidion aethiopicum RAFFRAY, 1886 n.
   syn.; Bembidion altipeta ALLUAUD, 1917 = Bembidion kilimanum ALLUAUD,
   1908 n. syn. Lectotypes for three species are herewith designated:
   Bembidion mixtum SCHAUM, 1863, Bembidion madagascariense CHAUDOIR, 1876
   and Bembidion mellissii WOLLASTON, 1869. We describe three new species:
   Bembidion demeyeri n. sp. (Uganda, Chad, Mali, Congo, Central African
   Republic, Tanzania, Burkina Faso); Bembidion gorilla n. sp. (Congo,
   Rwanda, Kenya, Tanzania); Bembidion uhligi n, sp. (S Africa, Zimbabwe,
   Swaziland, Namibia, Botswana, Zambia, Angola, Ethiopia, Kenya). A
   phylogenetic analysis of six species based upon DNA sequences from six
   genes reveals a strongly supported phylogeny, which suggests that the
   two species known from Madagascar came from two separate migrations to
   the island. An endemic species from Reunion Island, Bembidion alsium
   COQUEREL, 1866, included in the subgenus Omotaphus by JEANNEL (1946),
   shows striking exoskeletal peculiarities with respect to other species
   of the subgenus. As external characters give no indication of a
   relationship with subgenus Omotaphus, and as we have no aedeagal or
   molecular data for this species, we provisionally exclude the species
   from Omotaphus and declare it a species "incertae sedis".
C1 Toledano, Luca; Museo Civ Storia Nat, Lungadige Porta Vittoria 9,
   Verona, I-37129, Italy, Italy.
EM paolo.bonavita@istruzione.it
SC Zoology; Biochemistry &Molecular Biology; Genetics &Heredity;
   Evolutionary Biology
SN 0013-8835
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Type material; Synonymy; Taxonomy;
   Key; Documentation; Publications; Biochemistry; Genetics; Evolution;
   Land zones; Afrotropical region; Africa

   acids / Mt & nDNA sequences / taxonomic revision] [Molecular genetics / 
   / ] [Phylogeny /  / ] [Afrotropical region /  / ] [Africa /  / ].

   [Tanzania /  / ] [Uganda /  / ].

   [Namibia /  / ] [South Africa /  / ] [Swaziland /  / ] [Zambia /  / ]
   [Zimbabwe /  / ].

   Bembidion (Omotaphus) kilimanum - Alluaud 1908 (Carabidae): [Syn nov,
   Bembidion (Omotaphus) mixtum altipeta Alluaud 1917, p. 83].

   (Notaphus) variegatum Boheman 1848, p. 85; Syn nov, Bembidium tumidum
   Gemminger & Harold 1868, p. 85].

TI A new species of the genus Cephalota DOKHTOUROFF, 1883, and remarks on
   the taxonomy of other species (Coleoptera, Carabidae, Cicindelinae).
FT Eine neue Art der Gattung Cephalota DOKHTOUROFF, 1883 und Bemerkungen
   zur Taxonomie weiterer Arten (Coleoptera, Carabidae, Cicindelinae).
AU Gebert, Joerg (joerg.gebert@gmx.de) 
SO Entomologische Blaetter fuer Biologie und Systematik der Kaefer
VL 112
IS 1
PS 121-135
PD Oct 2016
PY 2016
LA German
U1 0
U2 0
AB Cephalota (Taenidia) hajdajorum n. sp. is described from northwestern
   Iran (Provinces of East and West Azerbaijan) and from the easternmost
   part of Turkey (Igdir). The lectotype of C. (Taenidia) zarudniana
   (TSCHITSCHERIN, 1903) is designated, and the status of that taxon and of
   its subspecies is clarified. C. zarudniana probsti (MANDL, 1976) is
   considered a junior synonym of C. zarudniana (TSCHITSCHERIN, 1903). C.
   (Taenidia) susanneae GEBERT, 1994 and C. (Taenidia)vartianorum (MANDL,
   1967) are raised to species rank.

DT Article
TI A remarkable new genus of the Oodini subtribe Sphaerodina JEANNEL, 1949
   from the Oriental Region (Coleoptera, Carabidae).
AU Gueorguiev, Borislav (gueorguiev@nmnhs.com) 
   Schmidt, Joachim
SO Entomologische Blaetter fuer Biologie und Systematik der Kaefer
VL 112
IS 1
PS 169-183
PD Oct 2016
PY 2016
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The genus Trichopalpoodes n. gen. with the type species Trichopalpoodes
   hiekei n. sp. (type locality: Uthai Thani, Thailand), is described from
   South-East Asia. Diagnostic features of the new genus and species are
   figured and the distribution is mapped. In order to determine the
   systematic position of the new genus within Oodini, diagnostic character
   states are discussed, and four remarkable autapomorphies are identified:
   i) ventral lobe of stipe, maxillary palpomeres 2-3, mentum, submentum
   and gula, each coarsely punctured and with some long setae; ii)
   maxillary palpomere 3 markedly elongate, nearly twice as long as
   palpomere 4; iii) glossal sclerite both reclinate and apically trifid;
   iv) elytron apically with a finer and narrower secondary ridge
   surrounded by apical stria and marginal gutter. An additional character
   of Trichopalpoodes n. gen. is unique within Oodini but is supposedly
   plesiomorphic: integument partially covered with short and scattered
   setae. As a result, Trichopalpoodes is classified as an isolated taxon
   within the pan-tropical Sphaerodina.
C1 Gueorguiev, Borislav; Natl Museum Nat Hist, 1 Blvd Tzar Osvoboditel,
   Sofia, 1000, Bulgaria, Bulgaria.
EM gueorguiev@nmnhs.com
SC Zoology
SN 0013-8835
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Oriental region;
   Eurasia; Asia
DE Trichopalpoodes hiekei [Cambodia /  / New species] [Malaysia /  / ]
   [Myanmar /  / ] [Thailand /  / ]. 
TN Arthropods; Beetles; Insects; Invertebrates

DT Article
TI The species of the genus Mastax FISCHER VON WALDHEIM, 1825 of the
   Himalaya (Coleoptera, Carabidae, Brachininae).
FT Die Arten der Gattung Mastax FISCHER VON WALDHEIM, 1825 im Himalaya
   (Coleoptera, Carabidae, Brachininae).
AU Hartmann, Matthias (matthias.hartmann@erfurt.de) 
SO Entomologische Blaetter fuer Biologie und Systematik der Kaefer
VL 112
IS 1
PS 185-202
PD Oct 2016
PY 2016
LA German
U1 0
U2 0
AB The species of the genus Mastax FISCHER VON WALDHEIM, 1825 Of the
   Himalayan region are reviewed. Two new synonyms are identified: Mastax
   fulvonotata QUENTIN, 1952 is proposed as a junior synonym of M. annulata
   ANDREWES, 1924 and Mastax rawalpindi JEDLICKA, 1963 is proposed as a
   junior synonym of M. laeviceps BATES, 1891. Alaska pakistana JEDLICKA,
   1963 described from Rawalpindi (Pakistan) is considered a subspecies of
   M. annulata ANDREWES, 1924. Figures of habitus and aedeagus are
   presented for all species considered in this paper, and a key to species
   is given. New records for Nepal and India are listed, and the catalogue
   of the Palearctic species of the genus Mastax is updated.
C1 Hartmann, Matthias; Nat Kundemuseum Erfurt, Grosse Arche 14, Erfurt,
   D-99084, Germany, Germany.

DT Article
TI Nebria (Patrobonebria) incognita n. sp and Nebria (P.) hiekeiana n. sp.,
   two new species from the Western Himalaya, with remarks on Nebria (P.)
   desgodinsi (Coleoptera, Carabidae, Nebriinae).
AU Huber, Charles (charles.huber@nmbe.ch) 
   Baur, Hannes
SO Entomologische Blaetter fuer Biologie und Systematik der Kaefer
VL 112
IS 1
PS 203-214
PD Oct 2016
PY 2016
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Nebria (Patrobonebria) incognita n. sp. and N. (R) hiekeiana n. sp. are
   described from the Western Himalaya. The type status of a supposed type
   specimen of N. (P.) desgodinsi OBERTHUR, 1883 is discussed in detail,
   and the specimen is excluded from the type series based on historical
   facts. Additional morphological characters are given for N. (P.)
   desgodinsi OBERTHUR, 1883, and also additional localities for N. (P)
   desgodinsi and N. (P.) capillosa LEDOUX & Roux, 1992. The species of the
   subgenus Patrobonebria are grouped based on the degree of protrusion of
   the eyes. A determination key for yellow-legged Patrobonebria species is
   given.

   Switzerland, Switzerland.

DT Article
TI A new species of the Anthracus angusticollis group from southern India,
   with notes on A. horni (ANDREWES, 1923) and A. vanharteni JAEGER &
   FELIX, 2009 (Coleoptera, Carabidae, Harpalini).
AU Jaeger, Bernd (acupalpus.bj@gmx.de) 
SO Entomologische Blaetter fuer Biologie und Systematik der Kaefer
VL 112
IS 1
PS 215-222
PD Oct 2016
PY 2016
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The Anthracus angusticollis group is introduced and characterized.
   Anthracus fritzhiekei sp. n. is described from southern India. The
   status of A. horni (ANDREWES, 1923) in the sense of former authors is
   discussed, and the taxon is regarded to be a complex of closely related
   taxa. A. vanharteni FELIX & JAEGER, 2009 which was previously only known
   from a single male from the Arabian Peninsula, is recorded from SW Iran,
   and additions to its characteristic are given.

AB A species new to science is described: Pseudognathaphanus hiekei n. sp.
   (type locality: Pokhara, Nepal). A short review of all Oriental species
   of the genus Pseudognathaphanus SCHAUBERGER, 1932, a key for their

   rufitactor BATES, 1892.

TI Information on Cyphon brevicollis LECONTE, 1866, with a description of
   Hiekecyphon n. gen. (Coleoptera, Scirtidae).
FT Zur Kenntnis von Cyphon brevicollis LECONTE, 1866 und Beschreibung von
   Hiekecyphon n. gen. (Coleoptera, Scirtidae).
AU Klausnitzer, B. (klausnitzer.col@t-online.de) 
SO Entomologische Blaetter fuer Biologie und Systematik der Kaefer
VL 112
IS 1
PS 237-244
PD Oct 2016
PY 2016
LA German
U1 0
U2 0
AB A supplementary description of Cvphon brevicollis LECONTE, 1865 is
   presented. Because this species cannot be attributed to Cyphon Paykull,
   1799, or to any other Scirtidae genus, the monotypic genus Hiekecyphon
   n. gen. is erected for Cyphon brevicollis LECONTE, 1865. The new genus
   is compared with those six Scirtidae genera which are characterized by
   the presence of a buttonhole-like impression near anterior lateral
   margin of the head.

DT Article
TI Synonymic, taxonomic and geographical notes on Bembidion (Peryphanes)
   dalmatinum hybridum APFELBECK, 1904 and B. (P.) adygorum BELOUSOV &
   SOKOLOV, 1996 (Coleoptera, Carabidae, Bembidiini).
AU Neri, Paolo
   Toledano, Luca (nerolit@alice.it) 
SO Entomologische Blaetter fuer Biologie und Systematik der Kaefer
VL 112
IS 1
PS 269-273
PD Oct 2016
PY 2016
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB The following synonymy is proposed: Bembidion (Peryphanes) dalmatinum
   hybridum APFELBECK, 1904 = B. (P.) dalmatinum dalmatinum DEJEAN, 1831 n.
   syn. The specimens from Turkey, formerly identified as B. (Peryphanes)
   dalmatinum hybridum, actually have to be referred to B. (P.) adygorum
   BELOUSOV & SOKOLOV, 1996, therefore the distribution of this species is
   extended to northern and eastern Turkey.

   Verona, I-37129, Italy, Italy.

PT J
AN ZOOR15303017922
DT Article
TI Trechini ground beetles from the Himalaya and the southern Tibetan
   Plateau with description of thirty-four new species and subspecies
   (Coleoptera, Carabidae).
AU Schmidt, Joachim (schmidt@agonum.de) 
SO Entomologische Blaetter fuer Biologie und Systematik der Kaefer
VL 112
IS 1
PS 301-363
PD Oct 2016
PY 2016
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Twenty-three new species and six new subspecies of Trechus CLAIRVILLE,
   1806 arc described from the Nepal Himalaya and from the central parts of
   the Greater Himalaya, Tibetan Himalaya and Transhimalaya in southern
   Tibet, People's Republic of China. Of these, 12 new species and six new
   subspecies are added to the species group of T. antonini DEUVE, 1997: T
   additus n. sp. (Transhimalaya), T budhaensis linchungensis n. ssp.
   (Transhimalaya), T christinae n. sp. (Transhimalaya), T dongola n. sp.
   (Tibetan Himalaya), T dromai n. sp. (Nyainqentanglha Shan), T frater n.
   sp. (Transhimalaya), T. frigophilus n. sp. (Nyainqentanglha Shan), T
   hiekei n. sp. (Transhimalaya), T hiekei subtiliformis n. ssp.
   (Transhimalaya), T menpa n. sp. (Transhimalaya), T. nami n. sp.
   (Nyainqentanglha Shan), T. neyamensis n. sp. (Transhimalaya), T
   parvifrater n. sp. (Transhimalaya), T religiosus birze n. ssp.
   (Transhimalaya), T religiosus lhai n. ssp. (Nyainqentanglha Shan), T
   religiosus nigropiceus n. ssp. (Nyainqentanglha Shan), T tsampa
   strialopunctatus n. ssp. (Transhimalaya), T utsi n. sp. (Transhimalaya).
   Two new species are added to the species group of T dacatraianus DEUVE,
   1996: T gyalmo n. sp. and T opgenoorthi n. sp., both from the
   Transhimalaya. One new species is added to the species group of T
   rolwalingensis SCHMIDT, 2009: T nyalamensis n. sp. (Greater Himalaya of
   South Central Tibet). Two new species are added to the species group of
   T wrzecionkoi DEUVE, 1996: T lhasaensis n. sp. and T mila n. sp., both
   from the Transhimalaya. A monotypic species group is newly established
   for T. gyalpo n. sp. (Transhimalaya). The species group of T. korrigani
   MORVAN, 1982, is newly established, and two new species are herein
   described: T phagunensis n. sp. and T sylviae n. sp., both from
   Mid-Western Nepal. The species group of T yasudai UENO, 1973, is newly
   established, and two new species are herein described: T kangchenjunga
   n. sp. and T nigrans n. sp., both from East Nepal. One new species could
   not be attributed to any of the known species groups and is therefore
   described within Trechus incertae sedis: T gyatsola n. sp. (Tibetan
   Himalaya). Trechus chaklaensis SCHMIDT, 2009, is recognised as a junior
   synonym of T wrzecionkoianus DEUVE, 2005. The male genital characters of
   T. yasudai UENO, 1973, are described for the first time. The true
   geographical positions of the type localities of the species T
   damchungensis DEUVE, 1997, T wrzecionkoianus DEUVE, 2005, and T
   (Setitrechus) setitemporalis DEUVE, 2005, are identified. New
   distributional data are presented for T budhaensis SCHMIDT, 2009, T
   damchungensis DEUVE, 1997, T. folwarcznyi DEUVE, 1997, T korrigani
   MORVAN, 1982, T morvanianus DEUVE & QUEINNEC, 1985, T tsampa SCHMIDT,
   2009, T yak SCHMIDT, 2009, and T yasudai UENO, 1973. Five new species
   and subspecies of Epaphiopsis UENO, 1953, subgenus Allepaphiama UENO &
   PAWLOWSKI, 1983, are described from the Eastern Himalaya: E. (A.) aruna
   n. sp. (East Nepal), E. (A.) arunachala n. sp. (Arunachal Pradesh
   District of India), E. (A.) kongma n. sp. (East Nepal), E. (A.)
   pathibhara n. sp. (East Nepal), and E. (A.) simbuaensis n. ssp. (East
   Nepal). Trechus bousqueti DEUVE, 1988, T chomolungma DEUVE & QUEINNEC,
   1985, T mumbugianus MATEU, 1985, T schawalleri DEUVE & HODEBERT, 1991, T
   simbuaensis DEUVE & HODEBERT, 1991, T tamurensis MINE & HODEBERT, 1991,
   and T thorectes Ueno, 1983 are newly combined with Epaphiopsis, subgenus
   Allepaphiama, and new distributional data are presented for these
   species. A brief overview to the species diversity patterns of the high
   altitude Trechini in different parts of the southern Himalaya-Tibet
   orogen is given and the particular importance of the Transhimalaya as a
   hotspot of alpine biodiversity is emphasized.
C1 Schmidt, Joachim; Univ Rostock, Inst Biosci Gen & Systemat Zool, Univ Pl
   2, Rostock, D-18055, Germany, Germany.
EM schmidt@agonum.de
SC Zoology; Environmental Sciences &Ecology
SN 0013-8835
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Diagnosis; Description;
   Combination; Synonymy; Taxonomy; Taxonomic position; Ecology; Community

TI Oxyporus hiekei n. sp. from China, a species with exceptional sexual
   dimorphism (Coleoptera, Staphylinidae, Oxyporinae).
FT Oxyporus hiekei n. sp. aus China, eine Art mit aussergewohnlichem
   Sexualdimorphismus (Coleoptera, Staphylinidae, Oxyporinae).
AU Schulke, Michael (mschuelke.berlin@t-online.de) 
SO Entomologische Blaetter fuer Biologie und Systematik der Kaefer
VL 112
IS 1
PS 365-372
PD Oct 2016
PY 2016
LA German
U1 0
U2 0
AB Oxyporus hiekei n. sp. from Yunnan (China) is described and illustrated.
   The systematic position of the new species, characterized by exceptional
   sexual dimorphism, is discussed. Based on a combination of characters
   unique in the genus Oxyporus FABRICIUS, 1775, assignment to any of the
   existing subgenera was not possible.

DT Article
TI Notes on the species of Plagiodera CHEVROLAT, 1836 of the Australian,
   Oceanic and Oriental regions, with a description of P. hiekei n. sp
   (Coleoptera, Chrysomelidae).
AU Sprecher-Uebersax, Eva (eva.sprecher@bs.ch) 
   Daccordi, Mauro
SO Entomologische Blaetter fuer Biologie und Systematik der Kaefer
VL 112
IS 1
PS 373-385
PD Oct 2016
PY 2016
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The genus Plagiodera is worldwide distributed. So far, 103 species are
   known. In the Neotropical region, 54 species have been described; three
   species are known from continental Australia, 23 from the Oriental and
   ten from the Oceanic region. In the Oriental, Australian and Oceanic
   regions two large species groups can be recognized based on the presence
   or absence of a carina on the first abdominal segment. During the study
   of these groups, one species from New Guinea was recognized as new to
   science, Plagiodera hiekei n. sp. It seems to be strongly endemic to the
   Oriental area of New Guinea, and is similar to P. riparia JACOBY, 1885,
   but differs in coloration, the punctuation of the elytra and the less
   enlarged aedeagus. Plagiodera sublaevis CHEN, 1934 becomes a new synonym
   of P. samoana MAULIK, 1929; Plagiodera pallida BALY, 1867 becomes
   Plagiosterna pallida (BALY, 1867) n. comb. Finally, some short notes on
   the biogeography of the species of Plagiodera arc presented.
C1 Sprecher-Uebersax, Eva; Nat Hist Museum, Augustinergasse 2, Basel,
   CH-4001, Switzerland, Switzerland.
EM eva.sprecher@bs.ch
SC Zoology
SN 0013-8835
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Combination; Synonymy; Taxonomy;
   Taxonomic position; Documentation; Publications; Zoogeography; Land
   zones; Australasian region; Oriental region; Eurasia; Asia; Australasia
DE Plagiodera [Catalogues /  / Systematics] [Zoogeography / Biogeography /
   ] [Oriental region /  / Distribution] [Australia /  / ] [ /  / ]
   [Oceanic islands /  / ] [ /  / ]. 
   Plagiodera hiekei [Indonesia /  / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Beetles; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Coleoptera, Polyphaga, Chrysomeloidea,
   Chrysomelidae

   Plagiodera hiekei (Chrysomelidae): [Sp nov, Indonesia, P. 374]. 
   Plagiodera pallida - Baly 1867 (Chrysomelidae): [Referred to,
   Plagiosterna, p. 376]. 
   Plagiodera samoana - Maulik 1929 (Chrysomelidae): [Syn nov, Plagiodera
   sublaevis Chen 1934, p. 376]. 
   Plagiosterna (Xenolina) marginata - Jacoby 1904 (Chrysomelidae):
   [Status, P. 376].

   Transferred from Plagiodera, p. 376].

PT J
AN ZOOR15303017925
DT Article
TI Two unexpected findings of the genus Ocys STEPHENS, 1828: a new species
   from China and another, giant, one from Iraq (Coleoptera, Carabidae,
   Bembidiini).
AU Toledano, Luca (lucatole2@libero.it) 
   Wrase, David W.
SO Entomologische Blaetter fuer Biologie und Systematik der Kaefer
VL 112
IS 1
PS 387-392
PD Oct 2016
PY 2016
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Ocys hiekei n. sp. (type loc.: China, Nei Mongol Autonomous Region,
   Helan Shan, above Guangzong temple, 38[degree]39'14.8''N
   105[degree]50'00.9''E, 2575 m) is described here, as the first member of
   the genus found in China. The other species described in this paper is a
   giant species found in Iraq, O. reuteri n. sp. (type loc.: North Iraq, S
   Rawanduz, 1400 m), representing the first record of the genus from Iraq.
   The species from China marks an unexpected and profound extension of the
   known distribution of a genus formerly thought to be restricted to the
   Western Palaearctic Region, from Portugal to Iran; we provide two new,
   isolated, spots in the distribution of the genus. The "Trechini-like"
   behaviour in some members of this genus, in general not very common in
   the Bembidiina, is supported by these new findings.
C1 Toledano, Luca; Museo Civ Storia Nat Verona, Lungadige Porta Vittoria 9,
   Verona, I-37129, Italy, Italy.
EM lucatole2@libero.it
SC Zoology
SN 0013-8835
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Palaearctic region;
   Eurasia; Asia; China
DE Ocys [China /  / New record] [Iraq /  / ]. 
   Ocys hiekei [Nei Mongol /  / New species]. 
   Ocys reuteri [Iraq /  / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Beetles; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Coleoptera, Adephaga, Caraboidea,
   Carabidae
OR Ocys (Carabidae): [New record]. 
   Ocys hiekei (Carabidae): [Sp nov, Nei Mongol, P. 390]. 
   Ocys reuteri (Carabidae): [Sp nov, Iraq, P. 388].

DT Article
TI Revision of the Erichsonius (Sectophilonthus) hiekei species group
   (Coleoptera, Staphylinidae, Staphylininae).
AU Uhlig, Manfred (manfred.uhlig@mfn-berlin.de) 
SO Entomologische Blaetter fuer Biologie und Systematik der Kaefer
VL 112
IS 1
PS 393-405
PD Oct 2016
PY 2016
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A revision of the Erichsonius (Sectophilonthus) hiekei species group,
   which is hereby introduced as monophyletic unit, is presented. Arguments
   for the monophyly of the group are stated. Photographs of E. (S.) hiekei
   UHLIG, 1995 (Zimbabwe: Manicaland: Inyanga Mountains) are given for the
   first time together with a short redescription. Another species is
   described as new: E. (S.) fritzi n. sp. (type locality: Democratic
   Republic of the Congo: South Kivu: Territory Kalehe S. W. Kahusi). The
   three species of the group, including E. (S.) dorsumsuis UHLIG & JANAK,
   2013 (South Africa: Eastern Cape, KwaZulu-Natal) are keyed and their
   distribution is mapped.
C1 Uhlig, Manfred; Leibniz Inst Evolut & Biodiversitatsforsch, Museum Nat
   Kunde, Invalidenstr 43, Berlin, D-10115, Germany, Germany.
EM manfred.uhlig@mfn-berlin.de

SN 0013-8835

   Documentation; Publications; Land zones; Afrotropical region; Africa

   Erichsonius (Sectophilonthus) hiekei species group [Illustrations /
   Photographs / Taxonomic revision] [Afrotropical region /  /
   Distribution].

PT J
AN ZOOR15303017927
DT Article
TI The Monolepta species of Namibia (Coleoptera, Chrysomelidae,
   Galerucinae).
AU Wagner, Thomas (thwagner@uni-koblenz.de) 
SO Entomologische Blaetter fuer Biologie und Systematik der Kaefer
VL 112
IS 1
PS 407-442
PD Oct 2016
PY 2016
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB All 13 Monolepta CHEVROLAT, 1836 species so far recorded from the
   Republic of Namibia are characterized, figured and distribution maps arc
   presented. For eight species, M. melanogaster (WIEDEMANN, 1823) (= M.
   pygidialis JACOBY, 1906, syn. n.), M capicola CHEVROLAT, 1836, M.
   cruciata GUERIN DE MENEVILLE, 1849, M. rubricosa GERSTAECKER, 1871, M
   vincta GERSTAECKER, 1871, M vinosa GERSTAECKER, 1871, M. amid WEISE,
   1906, and M ursulae WAGNER, 2003, taxonomic revisions have been
   published recently, and only figures, diagnosis and new distribution
   data arc given. For four species, M tricolor FAIRMAIRE, 1888 (= M
   zambesiana JACOBY, 1900, syn. n.), M citrinella WEISE, 1899 (= M.
   michaelseni WEISE, 1914, syn. n.; = M. eburnea LABOISSIERE, 1920, syn.
   n.; = M. poriensis LABOISSIERE, 1920, syn. n.; = M. oryzae BRYANT, 1948,
   syn. n.), M. livingstoni (JACOBY, 1900) comb. n. (originally described
   in the genus Candezea CHAPUIS, 1879), and M pimenteli LABOISSIERE, 1939,
   detailed redescriptions arc given here for the first time. Some other
   species originally described in Monolepta with type material from
   Namibia need to be transferred to other genera. Monolepta hiekei sp. n.
   is newly described in honour of the late FRITZ HICKS. Finally an
   identification key for the Namibian Monolepta species is presented.
   Monolepta melanogaster, M cruciata, M. rubricosa M vincta and M.
   tricolor are in Namibia only known from the wet tropical biomes in the
   Caprivi strip, while particularly M. livingstoni, M. citrinella, M
   ursulae, M. pimenteli and M hiekei sp. n. have a wide distribution in
   Namibia.
C1 Wagner, Thomas; Univ Koblenz Landau, Inst Integrierte Nat Wissensch
   Biol, Univ Str 1, Koblenz, D-56070, Germany, Germany.
EM thwagner@uni-koblenz.de
SC Zoology
SN 0013-8835

   Combination; Synonymy; Taxonomy; Taxonomic position; Key; Land zones;
   Afrotropical region; Africa

   revision].

DT Article
TI Systematics, taxonomy, and faunistics of Apomecynini of the Oriental and
   Australian Region (Coleoptera, Cerambycidae). Revision of the genus
   Sybra PASCOE, 1865, part 6: The Sybra alternans (WIEDEMANN, 1823)
   species group.
FT Systematik, Taxonomie und Faunistik der Apomecynini der orientalischen
   und australischen Region (Coleoptera, Cerambycidae). Revision der
   Gattung Sybra PASCOE, 1865, Teil 6: Die Gruppe der Sybra alternans
   (WIEDEMANN, 1823).
AU Weigel, Andreas (rosalia@versanet.de) 
   Skale, Andre
SO Entomologische Blaetter fuer Biologie und Systematik der Kaefer
VL 112
IS 1
PS 443-463
PD Oct 2016
PY 2016
LA German
U1 0
U2 0
AB The present contribution deals with five species related to Sybra
   alternans (WIEDEMANN, 1823) in a morphologically well defined species
   group, called the Sybra alternans-group: S. miscanthivola MAKIHARA,
   1977, S. multilineata (PIC, 1926) stat. rev., S. ordinata BATES, 1873
   and S. punctatostriata BATES, 1866. This species group is characterized
   by a typical morphology of the fibula of the endophallus. Assigned
   species are also differentiated from one another by a species-specific
   shape of the fibula. Following investigation of comprehensive material,
   many taxonomical changes and corrections become necessary. S.
   multilineata (Plc, 1926) stat. rev. is considered a valid species and
   not a junior synonym of S. alternans. The following synonymies are
   proposed (the senior synonym is listed first): S. alternans = S.
   ochreovittata BREUNING, 1939 n. syn.; S. ordinata BATES, 1873 = S.
   savioi PIC, 1925 n. syn. = S. loochooana BREUNING, 1939 n. syn. = S.
   albomaculata albomaculata BREUNING, 1939 n. syn. = S. subtesselata
   BREUNING, 1960 n. syn. = S. albomaculata formosana BREUNING, 1964 n.
   syn. = S. tenganensis BREUNING, 1965 n. syn. = S. masatakai MAKIHARA,
   2007 n. syn. All five species of the Sybra alternans group are
   illustrated, and a determination key and distribution map are presented.
C1 Weigel, Andreas; Schlossgarten 6, Wernburg, D-07381, Germany, Germany.
EM rosalia@versanet.de
SC Zoology
SN 0013-8835
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; Synonymy; Taxonomy; Key; Documentation;
   Publications; Land zones; Australasian region; Palaearctic region;
   Eurasia; Oceanic islands
DE Sybra alternans species group [Checklists / Updated checklist of species
   / ] [Asia /  / Distribution; systematics] [Australasia /  / ] [Pacific
   Ocean islands /  / ]. 
TN Arthropods; Beetles; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Coleoptera, Polyphaga, Chrysomeloidea,
   Cerambycidae
OR Sybra alternans - (Wiedemann 1823) (Cerambycidae): [Syn nov, Sybra
   ochreovittata Breuning 1939, p. 446; Removal from synonymy, Sybra
   multilineata (Pic 1927), p. 449]. 
   Sybra alternans species group (Cerambycidae): [Key to species, P. 445]. 
   Sybra multilineata - (Pic 1927) (Cerambycidae): [Removal from synonymy,
   With Sybra alternans (Wiedemann 1823), p. 449]. 
   Sybra ordinata - Bates 1873 (Cerambycidae): [Syn nov, Sybra albomaculata
   albomaculata Breuning 1939, p. 450; Syn nov, Sybra albomaculata
   formosana Breuning 1964, p. 450; Syn nov, Sybra loochooana Breuning

TI A small carabid for a great entomologist: Typhlocharis amara, a new
   species dedicated to Dr. FRITZ HIEKE (Coleoptera, Carabidae, Anillini).
AU Zaballos, J.P. (zaballos@ucm.es) 
   Andujar, C.
   Perez-Gonzalez, S.
SO Entomologische Blaetter fuer Biologie und Systematik der Kaefer
VL 112
IS 1
PS 465-473
PD Oct 2016
PY 2016
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new species of the genus Typhlocharis DIECK, 1869 is described from
   the Iberian Peninsula: Typhlocharis amara n. sp. The status as new
   species is supported by the presence of a unique configuration of the
   abdominal ventral foveae in the female. The distribution of the ventral
   foveae through the entire genus Typhlocharis is discussed, providing a
   classification of this character into five categories and the character
   state for each species.

DT Article
TI Taxonomic diversity of cockroach assemblages (Blattaria, Insecta) of the
   Aptian Crato Formation (Cretaceous, NE Brazil).
AU Lee, Shih-Wei (leesw@mail.nmmst.gov.tw) 
SO Geologica Carpathica
VL 67
IS 5
PS 433-450
PD Oct 2016
PY 2016
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB A comprehensive revision of 981 specimens of fossil cockroaches from the
   Lower Cretaceous laminated limestones of the Crato Formation of
   Northeast Brazil shows that they belong to eleven taxa, including
   Piniblattella limai, P. magna sp. n., Perlucipecta santanensis. sp. n.,
   Raptoblatta waddingtonae; Ocelloblattula santanensis sp. n., Elisama
   brevis (=E. americana, syn. n.), E. hindwingnii sp. n., Ponopterix
   axelrodi (=P. maxima syn. n.), Umenopterix burkhardi comb. n., and
   Cratovitisma oldreadi (Umenocoleidae=Cratovitismidae syn. n.
   =Ponopterixidae syn. n.). The family Ectobiidae is numerically most
   abundant in the assemblage of cockroaches of the Crato Formation (83 %
   of cockroaches), followed by Blattulidae (13 %) and Umenocoleidae (4 %).
   79.2 % of specimens are complete and fully articulated. Members of the
   family Alienopteridae are probably also present. Representatives of a
   relatively common Mesozoic superfamily Caloblattinoidea are missing.
   With the exception of the endemic genera Cratovitisma and Raptoblatta
   and the exclusively Gondwanan genus Ocelloblattula, all other genera
   were cosmopolitan. Taxonomic richness of cockroaches of the Crato
   Formation is thus rather low, and consists of geologically long-ranging
   and geographically-widespread genera, genera restricted to Gondwana, and
   short-ranging endemic genera found in the Crato Formation only.
C1 Lee, Shih-Wei; Natl Museum Marine Sci Technol, 367 Pei Ning Rd, Keelung,
   20248, Taiwan, Taiwan.
EM leesw@mail.nmmst.gov.tw
SC Zoology; Paleontology

DT Article
TI Enteromius vandewallei, a new species of minnow from the Volta River
   basin, West Africa (Cypriniformes: Cyprinidae).
AU Lederoun, Djiman (ldjiman@yahoo.fr) 
   Vreven, Emmanuel
SO Ichthyological Exploration of Freshwaters
VL 27
IS 2
PS 97-106
PD Oct 2016
PY 2016
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB Enteromius vandewallei, new species, is described from the Volta basin
   in Benin, Burkina -Faso, and Ghana, West Africa. Enteromius vandewallei
   belongs to the West African group of Enteromius for which the last
   simple dorsal fin ray is weekly ossified, flexible, and smooth on its
   hind margin. Enteromius vandewallei is most similar to E. nigeriensis to
   which it has erroneously been attributed in the past. It is nevertheless
   distinguishable from the latter by the following unique combination of
   characters: a narrow, continuous, blackish longitudinal band covering
   less than 1/2 scale in height and rising up to about 1 scale above the
   lateral line at the level of the dorsal fin (vs. blackish longitudinal
   band, whenever present, generally wider, covering at least 1/2 scale,
   sometimes discontinuous, and rising only up to approximately 1/2 scale
   above lateral line in E. nigeriensis); a long head, 26.4-28.4 % SL (vs.
   shorter, 22.6-25.7 in E. nigeriensis); and a narrow interorbital space,
   22-27 % HL (vs. wider, 27-36 in E. nigeriensis).
C1 Lederoun, Djiman; Univ Liege, Inst Chem B6, Liege, B-4000, Belgium,
   Belgium.
EM ldjiman@yahoo.fr

DT Article
TI Comparative morphology, phylogenetic relationships, and taxonomic
   revision of South American killifishes of the Melanorivulus zygonectes
   species group (Cyprinodontiformes: Rivulidae).
AU Costa, Wilson J.E.M. (wcosta@acd.ufrj.br) 
SO Ichthyological Exploration of Freshwaters
VL 27
IS 2
PS 107-152
PD Oct 2016
PY 2016
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB This study includes the first phylogenetic analysis for the M.
   zygonectes species group, a Glade of small rivulid killifishes, endemic
   to an area comprising the transitional zone between the Amazon rain
   forest and the Cerrado savannah, in central and northeastern Brazil. The
   phylogenetic analysis integrating 59 morphological characters and DNA
   sequences highly supports monophyly of the group. Fourteen species are
   considered valid, including eleven previously described, of which most
   had their distribution areas and diagnoses revised on the basis of
   recent new collections, and three new species: M. kayabi from the Rio
   Tapajos and middle Rio Xingu drainages; M. rubroreticulatus from the
   lower Rio Xingu drainage; M. modestus from the upper Rio Tapajos
   drainage; M. megaroni from the upper and middle Rio Xingu drainage; M.
   sahnonicaudus, M. spixi, new species, M. rubromarginatus, M. crixas, M.
   javaeh, M. karaja, and M. zygonectes, M. petrisecundi, new species, and
   M. wallacei, new species, from the Araguaia-Tocantins drainage system;
   and M. parnaibensis from the Rio Parnaiba basin. All clades contained in
   the M. zygonectes group have at least part of their members occurring in
   the Araguaia-Tocantins drainage system, a distribution pattern that is
   interpreted as evidence of a possible past distribution restricted to
   that area. This study once again supports the importance of using colour
   pattern characters of live specimens in systematics of aplocheiloid
   killifishes, since they were useful to diagnose species and sub-clades
   of the M. zygonectes group, besides increasing Glade support when added
   to molecular data.
C1 Costa, Wilson J.E.M.; Univ Fed Rio de Janeiro, Inst Biol, Caixa Postal
   68049, Rio De Janeiro, RJ, BR-21944970 BC, Brazil, Brazil.
EM wcosta@acd.ufrj.br

   America

   [Brazil /  / New species].

DT Article
TI Nothobranchius streltsovi, a new species of annual killifish with two
   male colour morphs from the Malagarasi drainage, central Tanzania
   (Teleostei: Cyprinodontiformes: Nothobranchiidae).
AU Valdesalici, Stefano (valdesalici.stefano@gmail.com) 
SO Ichthyological Exploration of Freshwaters
VL 27
IS 2
PS 153-161
PD Oct 2016
PY 2016
LA English
U1 0
U2 6
AB Nothobranchius streltsovi, new species, is described from specimens
   collected in pools associated with seasonal streams in upper catchments
   of the Ugalla River, Malagarasi drainage, central Tanzania. It belongs
   to the N. ugandensis species group based on male diagnostic characters
   comprising light blue scales with a broad, irregular reticulated pattern
   on the body, vivid red or orange oblique bars on the head and dorsum,
   yellow or blue anal fin, large vivid red spots on dorsal and anal fins,
   rounded head with a slightly concave to nearly straight dorsal profile,
   predorsal profile convex from nape to posterior extremity of dorsal -fin
   base, and variable cephalic squamation. Nothobranchius streltsovi has
   two sympatric colour morphs and is distinguished from all other members
   of the N. ugandensis group by the following combination of characters:
   scale margins orange; caudal fin orange, spotted proximally; pectoral
   fin spotted proximally; anal and pelvic fins with red dots, light blue
   proximally, yellow or creamy white distally; seven branchiostegal rays;
   31-34 longitudinal, 14-16 transverse, and 15-16 circumpeduncular scales;
   supraorbital neuromast formula 2 +3 +4.
C1 Valdesalici, Stefano; Via Ca Bertacchi 5, Viano, RE, I-42030, Italy,
   Italy.
EM valdesalici.stefano@gmail.com

TI Mystus nanus, a new striped catfish from Sri Lanka (Teleostei:
   Bagridae).
AU Sudasinghe, Hiranya (hsudasinghe@gmail.com) 
   Pethiyagoda, Rohan
   Maduwage, Kalana
   Meegaskumbura, Madhava
SO Ichthyological Exploration of Freshwaters
VL 27
IS 2
PS 163-172
PD Oct 2016
PY 2016
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB Mystus nanus, new species, is described from lowland streams, rivers and
   reservoirs throughout Sri Lanka. Previously misidentified in Sri Lanka
   as M. vittatus, the new species is distinguished from its Indian and Sri
   Lankan congeners by having two cream stripes along the flanks, a black
   hypural blotch, the distal margin of the dorsal fin rounded, eye
   diameter 19-22 % head length, adipose-fin base length 25.3-31.4 %
   standard length, and the posterior cranial fontanelle ending about an
   eye-diameter anterior to the base of the supraoccipital process.

DT Article
TI Garra mini, a new small species of rheophilic cyprinid fish (Teleostei:
   Cyprinidae) from southeastern hilly areas of Bangladesh.
AU Rahman, Md. Mizanur
   Mollah, Abdur Rob
   Noren, Michael
   Kullander, Sven O. (mizan.rahmanzool@du.ac.bd) 
SO Ichthyological Exploration of Freshwaters
VL 27
IS 2
PS 173-181
PD Oct 2016
PY 2016
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB Garra mini, new species, is described from the Shuvolong, Shailopropat
   and Chingthong waterfalls in the Karnafuli and Sangu River drainages.
   The largest specimens recorded is 46.8 mm SL and specimens over 40 mm SL
   have reached reproductive size. Alongside G. ethelwynnae (28 mm SL) and
   G. poecilura (44.5 mm SL), G. mini is one of the smallest species in the
   genus. Garra mini is diagnosed by morphological and meristic characters
   in combination, particularly the numerous small predorsal scales and the
   presence of a contrasted dark stripe along the middle of the side, and
   also by the DNA barcode sequence (cytochrome oxidase subunit I, COI)
   with three unique substitutions.
